title: Stocks Rise After Proposed Debt-Limit Extension; Gas prices edge lower in volatile trading after Russian President Vladimir Putin says country is ready to work on stabilizing the energy market
text:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rallied about 500 points, or 1.5%, to 34925. The S&P 500 added 1.5%. The Nasdaq Composite rose even higher as technology stocks recouped recent losses, lifting the benchmark up 1.7%.

"Right now, there are loads of fears out there. It just takes a couple of positive developments and suddenly that picture changes," said Lewis Grant, an equities portfolio manager at Federated Hermes.

Thursday's gains put stocks on firm footing for the week. All three major benchmarks are up at least 1.2% over the last four trading days. That marks a full recovery from Monday losses, when a selloff in Facebook stock and shares of other big technology companies rippled through the market.

On Thursday, technology and other growth stocks rallied. Shares of Apple, Microsoft and Google parent Alphabet all rose more than 1%. Twitter rose even higher, adding 3.1%. The company said Wednesday it would sell mobile ad firm MoPub to Applovin for $1.05 billion in cash.

Cyclical stocks also moved higher, as investors showed a willingness to snap up stocks at large. General Motors advanced nearly 4%, while Dow and Whirlpool both added around 3.5%.

Energy stocks also traded higher even as oil prices dipped, with futures for brent crude edging 0.3% lower to $80.83 a barrel. Russian President Vladimir Putin said Wednesday that Moscow was ready to work on stabilizing the global energy market, causing a sudden reversal in natural gas prices, which had earlier soared to their highest level on record. Halliburton added 1.1%, while Schlumberger rose nearly 3%.

Financial stocks rose 1.4%, and bond yields continued to creep up. The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose to 1.557% Thursday from 1.524% a day earlier. Yields and prices move inversely.

Fresh figures showed that 326,000 Americans applied for first-time unemployment benefits in the week ended Oct. 2, down from 364,000 the week prior.

Write to Caitlin Ostroff at caitlin.ostroff@wsj.com

In Europe, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 index jumped 1.6%, with gains led by the basic resources and auto sectors.

Indexes in Asia also closed higher. Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed 3.1%, led by gains in technology companies. Shares of Chinese Estates (Holdings) rose 32% in Hong Kong on Thursday after its majority shareholders offered to take the company private. The group is a major shareholder of embattled property giant China Evergrande Group.

South Korea's Kospi rallied 1.8%. The Nikkei 225 added 0.5%.
